title: How to Use Natural Cleaning Products

steps.headline: Pour a half cup of salt down clogged drains.
steps.description: The grit from salt has sandblasting properties to reduce and remove built-up scum. After pouring salt down the drain run warm water for a few minutes so it works its way through the system.

steps.headline: Remove grease from pans using a teaspoon of salt.
steps.description: Sprinkle liberally over the greasy pan and then follow up with a clean wet sponge or rag.

steps.headline: Sprinkle salt on hot oven food spills.
steps.description: Scrape away any superfluous food and then sprinkle salt on the spill. Allow to simmer for a few minutes before scraping away, followed by a wet washcloth.

methods.name: Using Vinegar to Remove Stains and Deodorize

steps.headline: Whiten grout using vinegar and an old toothbrush.
steps.description: Dip the toothbrush in vinegar and work it over the grout until stains lift. Wipe away dirt and mold and repeat.

steps.headline: Absorb kitchen smells.
steps.description: Last night’s fish still hanging around? Place a bowl of vinegar in the microwave and allow it to come to a boil. Set it on a kitchen counter and it will absorb remaining odor. Or, you can pour vinegar into a pan and simmer on the stove.

steps.headline: Remove stains on a tea kettle or coffee pot.
steps.description: Fill the kettle halfway with vinegar and allow it to come to a boil. Leave overnight, then rinse. For coffee, pour vinegar into a coffee maker and run through the system.

methods.name: Cleansing with the Power of Baking Soda

steps.headline: Eliminate tea or coffee mug stains with baking soda.
steps.description: Fill the mug with one part baking soda and two parts water. Allow to soak overnight, then rub clean the next day.

steps.headline: Lift laundry stains by adding a half cup of baking soda to the laundry detergent.
steps.description: Run on normal cycle to remove all over stains and brighten laundry.

steps.headline: Eliminate hard water stains by rubbing a half of a lemon over stained doors or sinks.
steps.description: Follow with a squeegee for an extra shine.

steps.headline: Remove food smells from hands.
steps.description: Garlic, onions or some meat will leave a lingering odor on the chef’s hands. Rub them with lemon juice and water and they’ll be restored to their natural aroma.

steps.headline: Bolster grease-fighting properties in dish soap.
steps.description: For extra greasy jobs, add a few drops of lemon juice to your regular dish soap to work through greasy pots and pans.

steps.headline: Shine shoes with a drop of olive oil on a clean, cotton cloth.
steps.description: Don't overdo it, as only one drop is needed to make both shoes shine.

steps.headline: Remove stickers or price tags with a few drops of olive oil and a little elbow grease.
steps.description: However, be careful if you're removing a sticker or tag on a cardboard item, as it may stain.

steps.headline: Polish and shine metal with a soft cotton cloth and a few drops of olive oil.
